title: How to Make Spaghetti Squash

steps.headline: Cut the spaghetti squash in half lengthwise using a sharp knife.
steps.description: Place the spaghetti squash on a dish towel so it doesn’t slip around when you cut it. To cut the squash in half, pierce the center of the squash with your knife. Then, cut from the center of the squash to one of the ends. Turn the squash around and cut from the center to the other end of the squash. Once you’ve cut almost all the way through the squash lengthwise, pull the 2 halves apart using your hands.

steps.headline: Scoop out the seeds inside the spaghetti squash with a spoon.
steps.description: The seeds are in the hollowed part on each half of the spaghetti squash. Place the spoon at one end of the hollowed part of the spaghetti squash and scrape it over to the other end to scoop out the seeds. Repeat until all of the seeds have been removed from both halves of the spaghetti squash.

steps.headline: Save the seeds if you want to roast them for a snack.
steps.description: To make roasted spaghetti squash seeds, simmer the seeds you scooped out of the spaghetti squash in salted water for 10 minutes. Then, pat the seeds dry with a dishcloth and toss them in olive oil and salt. Roast the seeds on a baking sheet in the oven at 325 °F (163 °C) for 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
steps.description: Lay the parchment paper flat on the baking sheet so it's covering the entire top of the sheet. This will help the spaghetti squash from sticking to the baking sheet when it's cooking.

steps.headline: Drizzle 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil onto each piece of spaghetti squash.
steps.description: Place the 2 halves on the baking sheet with the hollow, inside part facing up. Then, pour the olive oil over the upward-facing side of the squash so that both the hollowed-parts and cut edges have some oil on them. Then, spread the olive oil over the cut sides of the squash using your fingers.

steps.headline: Turn the 2 halves of spaghetti squash over on the baking sheet.
steps.description: Now, the cut sides of the squash should be facing down on the sheet, with the rounded outside part of the squash facing up. Roast the spaghetti squash like this so it gets tender in the oven.

steps.headline: Roast the spaghetti squash in the oven at 400 °F (204 °C) for 50 minutes.
steps.description: If you’re roasting a small spaghetti squash, it may need less time in the oven. Check on the spaghetti squash periodically to make sure it’s not burning.

steps.headline: Cook the spaghetti squash in the microwave if you’re short on time.
steps.description: Instead of using a baking sheet, put the 2 halves of spaghetti squash face down in a microwave-safe dish. Fill the dish with 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water. Then, microwave the spaghetti squash for 5-10 minutes, or until it's tender.

steps.headline: Let the spaghetti squash cool slightly.
steps.description: Don't let it cool all the way. You just want it cool enough so you're able to touch it without burning yourself. After the spaghetti squash has been out of the oven or microwave for a few minutes, touch it with the tip of your finger. If the spaghetti squash doesn't burn you, it's cool enough.

steps.headline: Scrape out the insides of the spaghetti squash using a fork.
steps.description: Flip the 2 halves of spaghetti squash over so the cut sides are facing up. Then, starting with one of the halves, take a fork and scrape it from one side of the spaghetti squash to the other. Do this throughout the whole inside of the spaghetti squash until you’ve scraped up all of the insides. When you’re finished, there should be a pile of thin strands of spaghetti squash inside the outer skin of the squash.

steps.headline: Transfer the scraped up spaghetti squash to a bowl and serve.
steps.description: Discard the spaghetti squash’s outer skin. Season the spaghetti squash to taste with salt and pepper. You can also top the spaghetti squash with grated parmesan cheese or fresh herbs.

text: Removing the Seeds Cut the spaghetti squash in half lengthwise using a sharp knife. Place the spaghetti squash on a dish towel so it doesn’t slip around when you cut it. To cut the squash in half, pierce the center of the squash with your knife. Then, cut from the center of the squash to one of the ends. Turn the squash around and cut from the center to the other end of the squash. Once you’ve cut almost all the way through the squash lengthwise, pull the 2 halves apart using your hands. Scoop out the seeds inside the spaghetti squash with a spoon. The seeds are in the hollowed part on each half of the spaghetti squash. Place the spoon at one end of the hollowed part of the spaghetti squash and scrape it over to the other end to scoop out the seeds. Repeat until all of the seeds have been removed from both halves of the spaghetti squash. Save the seeds if you want to roast them for a snack. To make roasted spaghetti squash seeds, simmer the seeds you scooped out of the spaghetti squash in salted water for 10 minutes. Then, pat the seeds dry with a dishcloth and toss them in olive oil and salt. Roast the seeds on a baking sheet in the oven at 325 °F (163 °C) for 20 minutes. Cooking the Spaghetti Squash Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Lay the parchment paper flat on the baking sheet so it's covering the entire top of the sheet. This will help the spaghetti squash from sticking to the baking sheet when it's cooking. Drizzle 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil onto each piece of spaghetti squash. Place the 2 halves on the baking sheet with the hollow, inside part facing up. Then, pour the olive oil over the upward-facing side of the squash so that both the hollowed-parts and cut edges have some oil on them. Then, spread the olive oil over the cut sides of the squash using your fingers. Turn the 2 halves of spaghetti squash over on the baking sheet. Now, the cut sides of the squash should be facing down on the sheet, with the rounded outside part of the squash facing up. Roast the spaghetti squash like this so it gets tender in the oven. Roast the spaghetti squash in the oven at 400 °F (204 °C) for 50 minutes. If you’re roasting a small spaghetti squash, it may need less time in the oven. Check on the spaghetti squash periodically to make sure it’s not burning. Cook the spaghetti squash in the microwave if you’re short on time. Instead of using a baking sheet, put the 2 halves of spaghetti squash face down in a microwave-safe dish. Fill the dish with 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water. Then, microwave the spaghetti squash for 5-10 minutes, or until it's tender. Serving the Spaghetti Squash Let the spaghetti squash cool slightly. Don't let it cool all the way. You just want it cool enough so you're able to touch it without burning yourself. After the spaghetti squash has been out of the oven or microwave for a few minutes, touch it with the tip of your finger. If the spaghetti squash doesn't burn you, it's cool enough. Scrape out the insides of the spaghetti squash using a fork. Flip the 2 halves of spaghetti squash over so the cut sides are facing up. Then, starting with one of the halves, take a fork and scrape it from one side of the spaghetti squash to the other. Do this throughout the whole inside of the spaghetti squash until you’ve scraped up all of the insides. When you’re finished, there should be a pile of thin strands of spaghetti squash inside the outer skin of the squash. Transfer the scraped up spaghetti squash to a bowl and serve. Discard the spaghetti squash’s outer skin. Season the spaghetti squash to taste with salt and pepper. You can also top the spaghetti squash with grated parmesan cheese or fresh herbs.
